details.title: Lifetime Estimation Using Only Failure Information From Warranty Database
details.standardTitle: Lifetime Estimation Using Only Failure Information From Warranty Database

p: Md. Mesbahul Alam is an Assistant Professor at the Department of Statistics, University of Rajshahi, Rajshahi, Bangladesh. Presently, he is a Ph.D. candidate in the Department of Information Management Science, The University of Electro-Communications, Tokyo, Japan. He received the B.Sc. Honours degree in 1991, and M.Sc. degree in 1992, both in Statistics from the University of Rajshahi, Rajshahi, Bangladesh. His research interests focus on reliability data analysis, warranty, optimization, robust statistics, and regression diagnostics. He is a life member of BSA, IJSS, and student member of the JSQC.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Inf. Manage. Sci., Univ. of Electro-Commun., Chofu, Japan
authors.name: M. Mesbahul Alam

p: Kazuyuki Suzuki (M'92) received a Ph.D. degree (1979) from the Tokyo Institute of Technology. He is currently a professor in the Dept. of Systems Engineering, at the University of Electro-Communications. His research interests include optimal conditioning monitoring, optimal reliability testing, and analysis of lifetime data. He was awarded the Wilcoxon Prize (1999), the Nikkei Quality Control Literature Prize (1977, 1986, 2005), and Takagi Literature Prize (1995, 2003, 2006). He has been a member of the Deming Prize Committee since 1990. He has served as the chair of IEEE Reliability Society Japan Chapter, and the editor for both the Japanese Society for Quality Control (JSQC) and the Reliability Engineering Association of Japan (REAJ), and is on the board of both societies. He is currently a vice-president of JSQC.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Inf. Manage. Sci., Univ. of Electro-Commun., Chofu, Japan
authors.name: Kazuyuki Suzuki

details.abstract: Knowledge about product lifetime obtained from actual usage (field data) is of great importance to manufacturers who want to get information about the true reliability of their products. Warranty data are frequently used to estimate reliability characteristics because such databases are automatically generated and updated at no additional cost from repair claims during warranty coverage. For engineering purposes, usage time (e.g., mileage) is more relevant, and lifetime parameters measured in usage time is an integral part of reliability analysis using warranty data. Usually, warranty data consist of only failure information. Censored data (e.g., mileage of non-failure automobiles) are not obtainable, of which usage time distributions are different from those of failed ones. Effective usage-based estimation thus requires supplementary information about usage accumulation for non-failure units such as follow-up studies, or a usage time distribution which includes both failure, and non-failure products. However, sometimes usage-based data for non-failed units are expensive and difficult to obtain. Thus, the unavailability of the usage time of censored units makes it difficult to estimate the usage-based lifetime distribution of products. This paper deals with that problem, and discusses how to estimate the lifetime distribution using warranty data which consist of only failure information. The practical consequence of this finding is that supplemental information is not needed to obtain correct estimates of the lifetime parameters.

links.abstract: Time or mileage data obtained from warranty claims are generally more accurate for hard failures than for soft failures. For soft failures, automobile users sometimes delay reporting the warranty claim until the warranty coverage is about to expire. This results in an unusually high number of warranty claims near the end of warranty coverage. Because such a phenomenon of customer-rush near the warranty expiration limit occurs due to user behavior rather than due to the vehicle design, it creates...

context.text:
Numerous papers [1], [3], [16]–

[19]



[23] discuss how warranty data can be used to estimate the lifetime parameters of usage-at-failure distributions.
Many previous works on the estimation of failure distributions as functions of usage have implicitly assumed that usage-at-failure is \$s\$-independent of usage accumulation or usage rate [18], [19].
Rai & Singh [19] demonstrated that a lognormal distribution provides a good fit for mileage accumulation data with a linear trend between mileage at \$t\$ MIS, \$Y_{t}\$ versus MIS \$t\$.
Here, we set \$\mu=7.3\$, and \$\sigma=0.7\$, as obtained from a real data set in [19].

To know the partial information of the censored usage time or usage time distribution, supplementary data are important [1], [3], [16]–

[19]



[23].

context.text:
Numerous papers [1], [3], [16]–




[22]
[23] discuss how warranty data can be used to estimate the lifetime parameters of usage-at-failure distributions.

Now, to get an overview of the assumed models, we go through the nonparametric estimation of the lifetime distributions as given by Wang & Suzuki [22], and probability plotting procedures by using the MLE of the parameters of the lognormal distribution as a censoring variable.

With known censoring distribution, the nonparametric MLE \$\mathhat{F}_{a}(x)\$ of \$F_{a}(x)\$, and \$\mathhat{F}_{b}(x)\$ of \$F_{b}(x)\$, as given in [22] are where \$d_{a}(x_{k})\$, and \$d_{b}(x_{k})\$ are the number of failures at support point \$x_{k}(x_{k}< x_{k+1})\$ with failure modes 1, and 2 respectively.
The Weibull probability plot based on the nonparametric cdf estimate for failure mode 1 by using the method of Wang & Suzuki [22].
The exponential probability plot based on the nonparametric cdf estimate for failure mode 2 by using the method of Wang & Suzuki [22].
The Weibull probability plot based on the nonparametric cdf estimate for failure mode 1 by using the method of Wang & Suzuki [22].
The exponential probability plot based on the nonparametric cdf estimate for failure mode 2 by using the method of Wang & Suzuki [22].
